[[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[Air Vice Marshal]] '''Richard Anthony "Tony" Mason''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|CB|CBE|DL}} (born 22 October 1932) is a retired senior commander of the [[Royal Air Force]] who became [[Air Secretary]]. ==Early life== Mason was born on 22 October 1932,{{cite web|title=Air Vice Marshal Tony Mason, CB, CBE, DL|url=http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/m/18139/Richard%20Anthony%20%28Tony%29+MASON.aspx|work=People of Today|publisher=Debrett's|accessdate=4 November 2012}} the son of William and Maud Mason.{{cite web|title=MASON, Air Vice-Marshal Richard Anthony, (Tony)|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whoswho/U26907|work=Who's Who 2012|publisher=A & C Black|accessdate=4 November 2012|date=November 2011}} He was educated at the then all-boys [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|independent]] [[Bradford Grammar School]] and at the [[University of St Andrews]], from where he graduated with a [[Master of Arts (Scotland)|Master of Arts]] (MA). ==Military career== Mason was [[commissioned officer|commissioned]] into the Education Branch of the [[Royal Air Force]] as a [[flying officer]] on 29 June 1956 with the [[service number]] 504826.{{London Gazette |issue=40875 |date=7 September 1956 |startpage=5162 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} Promoted to [[flight lieutenant]] on 29 December 1958,{{London Gazette |issue=41598 |date=2 January 1959 |startpage=159 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} he was appointed to a permanent commission on 1 July 1959.{{London Gazette |issue=41859 |date=30 October 1959 |startpage=6937 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} He was promoted to [[squadron leader]] on 17 February 1963{{London Gazette |issue=42924 |date=15 February 1963 |startpage=1616 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} and to [[Wing commander (rank)|wing commander]] on 1 July 1970.{{London Gazette |issue=45138 |date=26 June 1970 |startpage=7195 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} He attended the [[United States Air Forces]]'s [[Air War College]] located in [[Maxwell Air Force Base]], [[Montgomery, Alabama]] in 1971 and the RAF's [[RAF Staff College, Bracknell|Staff College]] in [[Bracknell]], [[Berkshire]] in 1972. He became Director of Defence Studies in 1976. He was promoted to [[group captain]] on 1 January 1977.{{London Gazette |issue=47117 |date=10 January 1977 |startpage=371 |endpage=373 |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} In the 1981 [[Queen's Birthday Honours]], he was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE).{{London Gazette |issue=48639 |date=12 June 1981 |startpage=1 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} He was appointed Director of Personnel (Ground) in 1982, and promoted to [[air commodore]] on 1 January 1983 as part of the half-yearly promotions.{{London Gazette |issue=49237 |date=17 January 1983 |startpage=759 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-05}} He became [[Air Secretary]] in 1985, having been Deputy Air Secretary in 1984. He was promoted to [[air vice marshal]] on 1 January 1986, once again as part of the half-yearly promotions.{{London Gazette |issue=50398 |date=13 January 1986 |startpage=562 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-05}} He was appointed [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] (CB) in the 1988 Queen's Birthday Honours.{{London Gazette |issue=51365 |date=10 June 1988 |startpage=3 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-04}} He was succeeded as Air Secretary by Air Vice Marshal [[Robert Honey]] on 10 February 1989.{{London Gazette |issue=51650 |date=20 February 1989 |startpage=2179 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-05}} He retired from the Royal Air Force on 22 April 1989.{{London Gazette |issue=51754 |date=5 June 1989 |startpage=6664 |endpage= |supp=yes |accessdate=2012-11-05}} ==Later life== Following his retirement from the RAF, Mason became an academic. In 1996, he was made an [[honorary professor]] of the [[University of Birmingham]]. He had been Director of its Centre for Studies in Security and Diplomacy{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.speakeasier.org/about|publisher=Speakeasier Charity|accessdate=5 November 2012|year=2012}} from 1988 to 2001. He was a specialist air adviser to the [[House of Commons Defence Committee]] between 2001 and 2006.{{cite web|title=R. A. "Tony" Mason|url=http://www.potomacbooksinc.com/resrcs/frontm/1597975559_contlink.pdf|work=Global Air Power Contributor Bios|accessdate=5 November 2012}} He was made an Honorary Fellow of the [[Royal Aeronautical Society]] (Hon FRAeS) in 2006. In March 2002, he was commissioned a [[Deputy Lieutenant]] (DL) to the [[Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire]].{{London Gazette |issue=56516 |date=22 March 2002 |startpage=3601 |endpage= |supp= |accessdate=11 February 2013}} ==Family== In 1956 he married Margaret Sneddon Stewart; they had two daughters Lindsay and Pamela (died 1985).Debrett's People of Today 1994 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Published works== *The Aerospace Revolution: Role Revision and Technology – An Overview *Mason, Tony ''To Inherit the Skies: From Spitfire to Tornado'', Brassey, 1990, ISBN 0-08-040708-0 *Mason, Tony ''Air Power: a Centennial Appraisal'', Brassey's, 2003, ISBN 978-1-85753-322-4 {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box| title=[[Air Secretary]]| before=[[Barry Duxbury|Sir Barry Duxbury]]| after=[[Robert Honey]]| years=1985–1989}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mason, Tony}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Bradford Grammar School]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of St Andrews]] [[Category:Royal Air Force air marshals]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Gloucestershire]]
